metadata.case_name: Pramatha Nath Talukdar and Saurindra Mohan Basu v. Saroj Ranjan Sarkar

facts.text: Nalini Ranjan Sarkar was Governing/Managing Director of N.R. Sarkar Co. Ltd., managing several public companies; held 4649 shares; obtained leave of absence on January 4, 1948 to join West Bengal Ministry as Finance Minister on January 23, 1948.

On July 31, 1951, Nalini Ranjan Sarkar executed deed of trust for 3649 shares of N.R. Sarkar Co. Ltd., appointing Promode Ranjan Sarkar, Pramatha Nath Talukdar, Narendra Nath Law as trustees; beneficiaries his brothers including Saroj Ranjan Sarkar and Santi Ranjan Sarkar; balance 1000 shares allegedly kept with Pramatha Nath Talukdar for benefit of brothers.
Nalini Ranjan Sarkar died on January 25, 1953.

Few days after funeral, Saurindra Mohan Basu informed Promode Ranjan Sarkar of two documents: unregistered deed of agreement dated January 19, 1948 appointing Pramatha Nath Talukdar as Managing Director of N.R. Sarkar Co. Ltd., and deed of transfer of 1000 shares dated February 5, 1951 to Pramatha Nath Talukdar; request to see documents not complied with.
Pramatha Nath Talukdar resigned from Hindusthan Co-operative Insurance Society Ltd. end July 1953, sought control of N.R. Sarkar Co. Ltd. as Managing Director; led to trouble and correspondence.
On September 22, 1953, Board meeting of N.R. Sarkar Co. Ltd. allegedly irregular, renewed appointment of Pramatha Nath Talukdar as Managing Director for 7 years despite protest.

September 1953, Promode Ranjan Sarkar wrote for inspection of deeds; inspected October 1, 1953, photographed relevant portions October 13, 1953; inspected minutes, alleged forgery of January 16, 1948 proceedings bearing Nalini Ranjan Sarkar's signature.

Allegations of forgery of three documents in conspiracy: (1) unregistered deed of agreement dated January 19, 1948 appointing Pramatha Nath Talukdar Managing Director, signature of Nalini Ranjan Sarkar forged, attested by Saurindra Mohan Basu; (2) transfer deed 1000 shares February 5, 1951; (3) minutes of Board meeting January 16, 1948 on letterhead with City 6091 (exchange existed Dec 1948, connection March 1949).

First complaint by Promode Ranjan Sarkar on March 17, 1954 against appellants and others under ss.467,471/109 IPC; dismissed under s.203 CrPC by Chief Presidency Magistrate N.C. Chakravarti on August 6, 1954.
Revision Cr. Rev. No.1059/1954 dismissed by Debabrata Mookerjee J. on July 8, 1955.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court February 13, 1956; appeal filed but withdrawn February 3, 1959 stating settlement at intervention of friends; withdrawn March 12, 1959.
Second complaint by Saroj Ranjan Sarkar on April 3, 1959 against appellants, Narendra Nath Law, Amiya Chakravarty under ss.467,471/109 IPC.
Chief Presidency Magistrate Bijayesh Mukherjee issued process against appellants only on April 11, 1959; found no delay, no bar from first dismissal, prima facie forgery of deed and minutes.
Revisions Cr. Rev. Nos.1019 & 681/1959 heard by Division Bench P.B. Mukherjee & H.K. Bose JJ., referred to larger Bench; Special Bench of 3 Judges dismissed revisions December 22/23, 1960.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court April 10, 1961; appeals 75 & 77/1961 against Dec 22/23 order; 76 & 78 withdrawn.

legal_issues.text: Whether a second complaint can be entertained by a Magistrate who or whose predecessor had dismissed a previous complaint on the same or similar allegations, and if so, in what circumstances.
Whether the Special Bench of Calcutta High Court was lawfully seised and competent to deal with the revisions.
Whether Chief Presidency Magistrate had jurisdiction to take cognizance absent sanction under s.196A CrPC for criminal conspiracy.

petitioner_arguments.text: Second complaint not entertainable as law prohibits it after dismissal under s.203 CrPC unless set aside under ss.436/439 CrPC; s.403 CrPC bars; follow Nilratan Sen and Kamal Chandra Pal.
Complaint discloses criminal conspiracy u/ss.120A/120B IPC (non-cognizable offence), requires consent u/s.196A(2) CrPC; no consent obtained.
Division Bench could not refer to larger Bench absent proviso to r.9 Ch.II Calcutta HC Rules; only if equally divided s.429 CrPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Calcutta HC Rules Ch.II; s.429 CrPC

petitioner_arguments.text: No prima facie case against Saurindra Mohan Basu.

respondent_arguments.text: Dismissal u/s.203 not bar to second complaint; exceptional circumstances: manifest error/misapplication of ss.203/204 by first Magistrate (treated as full trial), new evidence on City 6091 telephone (not considered earlier).
Complaint discloses abetment by conspiracy u/s.107 IPC (s.467/471 r/w s.109), not criminal conspiracy u/s.120B; no sanction needed u/s.196A; distinct offences alleged.
No undue delay; not blackmail; prima facie case on materials.

court_reasoning.text: Special Bench lawfully constituted; Chief Justice has inherent power to constitute larger Bench on reference, especially where earlier DB decisions questioned.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules allow; principle of Ch.VII rr.1,5 applies by analogy.

court_reasoning.text: No violation of s.196A; complaint alleges abetment by conspiracy (s.107 IPC) requiring overt act, not mere criminal conspiracy (s.120A); distinct from ss.467/471; no sanction for latter.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Test: essential offences disclosed; drafting not decisive; Basir-ul-Huq principle applies.

court_reasoning.text: No absolute bar to second complaint after s.203 dismissal (not acquittal u/s.403); but exceptional circumstances needed: manifest error, miscarriage of justice, or new facts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Courts uniform; first Magistrate misdirected (applied conviction standards, not prima facie); new telephone evidence decisive for forgery.

court_reasoning.text: First Magistrate erred in scope of s.203/204 inquiry (prima facie, not full trial); Debabrata Mookerjee J. erred refusing City 6091 evidence; withdrawal of SL appeal suspicious.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Manifest miscarriage; serves justice to proceed.

holdings.text: Magistrate competent to entertain second complaint if exceptional circumstances (manifest error, miscarriage, new facts) exist despite prior s.203 dismissal.
No sanction u/s.196A needed where abetment by conspiracy (with overt acts) and substantive forgery alleged, distinct from criminal conspiracy.
Here, exceptional circumstances exist; prima facie case; dismiss appeals.

precedents_cited.relevance: Held second complaint barred; not accepted.
No bar to second complaint unless manifest error/miscarriage.

No bar; exceptional circ including new facts.

outcome.summary: K. Das J. (dissenting) would dismiss the appeals upholding the Calcutta High Court Special Bench order dismissing revisions against issuance of process on second complaint; finds exceptional circumstances justify second complaint; no s.196A violation; Special Bench competent. (Majority view by Kapur J. for self and Hidayatullah J. differs, text incomplete.)

key_quotes.text: The principal question which arises for decision in these two appeals is whether a second complaint can be entertained by a Magistrate who or whose predecessor had, on the same or similar allegation, dismissed a previous complaint, and if so in what circumstances should such a second complaint be entertained.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Frames core issue of general importance.

key_quotes.text: Prima facie, I am satisfied about the truth of the allegations the complaint makes. That apart, the complaint is for an offence triable by a Court of sessions. And the materials I see before me are such as in my opinion may lead a reasonable body of men to believe the truth thereof.
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: Chief Presidency Magistrate's basis for issuing process u/s.204 CrPC.

key_quotes.text: The test whether sanction is or is not necessary does not depend on mere astuteness of drafting the petition of complaint.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: There is nothing in law which prohibits the entertainment of a second complaint on the same allegations when a previous complaint had been dismissed under s.203 CrPC.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects absolute bar; requires exceptional circumstances.

key_quotes.text: Sufficient ground for proceeding with the complaint is one matter and sufficient ground for convicting an accused person is quite a different matter.
key_quotes.speaker: court
